title: Settler Creations
text:
Before the arrival of the colonists in 1607, what is now known as the United States did not look anything like what we see on a map today. Indigenous nations and their people did not draw boundary lines like what the Federal Government did to divide Indigenous land into states.
Jessica Taylor, in Plain Paths and Dividing Lines: Navigating Native Land and Water in the Seventeenth-Century Chesapeake, states that Algonquian-speaking groups on the Virginia coast “transformed Chesapeake waterways into lines of connection between families and towns.”1 Instead of marking lines of ownership, the natural world offered a sense of kinship and community.
Theda Perdue noted similar patterns among the early eighteenth century Cherokee. Part of the Iroquoian language family, the Cherokee people “spoke several dialects of a common language…but no clear boundaries demarcated their territory and no political authority delineated citizenship.”2 Though no Native American culture is the same, the similarities between the Cherokee in present-day Oklahoma and Algonquian-speakers like as the Appamattucks are important to recognize.

title: Settler Creations
text:
Boundaries and Settler Encroachment
Boundaries can be described as “the imaginary, geographical places where assertions of property or sovereignty begin and end, made by practices of marking them on trees or measuring them with survey instruments or reminding one another that the line marks a division between at least two different places.”3
Since the seventeenth century, acts of violence against the Indigenous people of this land have been waged. The forced removal and relegation of Indigenous people to reservations in the nineteenth century were acts of organized violence by settler-colonial institutions. The actions taken by the Federal Government are indicative of an attempt to assert its’ sovereignty and deny the same ability to the thousands of Indigenous people that were forced to leave their ancestral lands.

title: Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute and the Indian Program
text:
In 1878, the Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute began its’ program with seventeen Indigenous men. Those brought to Hampton were “chiefly Kiowas and Cheyennes,” who had been held as prisoners of war in Fort Marion, Florida, by Captain Richard Henry Pratt in the aftermath of the Red River War of 1874-75.1
Later the same year, Secretary of the Interior Carl Schurz requested that the Institute “collect” fifty Indigenous children from “Sioux” territory. Part of this area is now known as Wisconsin and Minnesota.2 These children arrived in November and thus began the “Indian Program.”
The Program itself lasted until 1923, only a year before the destructive and eugenicist Virginia Racial Integrity Act. The location of the Hampton Institute and structure of its’ Program is only one testament to the Commonwealth of Virginia and the Federal Government’s goals of assimilation and cultural destruction.

title: Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute and the Indian Program
text:
Indigenous Students at Hampton Institute
There were Indigenous students from over 65 different nations at Hampton Institute. The largest population of students affiliated themselves with the Oneida, Lakota, Dakota, and Eastern Band Cherokee. As stated on other parts of this website, Indigenous cultures did not organize space or their world in the same way that Europeans did. However, as the ones in positions of power, white settlers carved out these states to suit their own needs, disregarding traditional knowledge surrounding the land itself.
It is important to note that the Lakota cared for the land in what is now Wyoming, Nebraska, North and South Dakota, and Montana. However, in 1876, the Black Hills were taken by the Federal government, forcing the Lakota onto limited reservations in South Dakota and Northern North Dakota.
